comments:
I believe the problem might be that uint32_t is not defined. From GDB console:

whatis $pc
type = uint32_t
ptype uint32_t
No symbol "uint32_t" in current context.
ptype $pc
type = uint32_t

When I try to manually cast $pc to int, I get an exception:

- how do I know where in the CVS repository to look?

seing these "fixed" reports, but it would be nice to review the code.

> - are changes committed before bugs are closed?

They are commited to the head or whatever branch the "Target Milestone"
points out.

> - how do I know where in the CVS repository to look?

in this case, VariableManager in the mi plugin.

> Normally I just do a Team->Update and launch the freshly built CDT + test 
when 
> seing these "fixed" reports, but it would be nice to review the code.

It depends when the nightly builds are distributed.

I though you build things straing from the head branch of CDT ?

> When I type in something incorrectly to the "cast to type" request, 
> like "(int)", I get the error messages below:

this is normal, you try to cast to a type that does not exist,
the "(int)" does not exist ... however "int" does ..

Unfortunately gdb is not very clear in its error messages, I will have
to agree that:
         "A syntax error in expression, near `"
Does not say much, but for this not much we can do.

Now whether "(int)" should be seen as "int" meaning the debugger
should have parse the expression is debatable.

I would like to turn this to fixed any objections ?
>I though you build things straing from the head branch of CDT ?

I think I do. :-)

Is there a method for translating from PR # to CVS commit/ChangeLog?

I guess I'm asking silly questions in my ignorance.

BTW, I looked at the cdt-cvs mailing list and the last archived post is Jan-02-
2004(with a gap until Nov-2003).

?yvind
>I would like to turn this to fixed any objections ?

Yes.

- viewing registers in hexadecimal still does not work.
- if I type (int) by accident(or any syntax error?), 
I get an error message(as expected), but if I type in the correct
"int" afterwards, the GUI seems to be "stuck" on the poisoned 
cast.

I don't care about the error messages particularly.

?yvind
> I get an error message(as expected), but if I type in the correct
> "int" afterwards, the GUI seems to be "stuck" on the poisoned 
cast.
> 
> I don't care about the error messages particularly.

You are absolute right, I fix the casting problem, but that
still will not "unstuck" the GUI, as you put it.

Mikhail, you seem to dispose() of the variable, in the casting.
(this goes also for castingAsArray())

	public void cast( String type ) throws DebugException {
		InternalVariable current = getCurrentInternalVariable();
		if ( current != null ) {
			InternalVariable newVar = current.createShadow( type );
			if ( getShadow() != null )
				getShadow().dispose();
			setShadow( newVar );
			fireChangeEvent( DebugEvent.STATE );
		}
	}

But meanwhile since the selection is on that variable, that was cache
you call variable.getValue().getValueString() or something on the variable
that you just deleted ? it seems to be a classic race condition.

To reproduce, cast the "eax" register to "int" cast it a second time
to "int" again and do "restore variable"

Thanks
> - are changes committed before bugs are closed?

Yes !!

> - how do I know where in the CVS repository to look?

There is a mailing list with all the diff of the recent commits
Now, unfortunately I do not remember the URL.  Please ask the question
to the cdt-dev mailing list, I'm sure one the IBM guys who made the setup
will answer. If not ping me again.
fix in the head and branch CDT_21
please verify.
1) Viewing $pc as hex, still shows $pc as decimal.

2) If I cast to int(from uint32_t), it shows as hex.

The latter is an improvement.

It still isn't possible to view expressions as hex, but I believe that is a
known issue.

?yvind
> 1) Viewing $pc as hex, still shows $pc as decimal.
> 2) If I cast to int(from uint32_t), it shows as hex.
> The latter is an improvement.
> It still isn't possible to view expressions as hex, but I believe that is a
> known issue.

What is the type of the "pc" ? i.e. what does CDT shows for type for
this register ?(click the little X button to enable types in the register 
view).


>What is the type of the "pc" ? i.e. what does CDT shows for type for
>this register ?(click the little X button to enable types in the register 
>view)

uint32_t
The format action doesn't work because the "uint32_t" type is not recognized by 
the CDI implementation. Reassigning to Alain.
> uint32_t

That really suck!! in any other gdb I have:
(gdb) ptype uint32_t
type = long unsigned int
(gdb) whatis uint32_t
type = long unsigned int
(gdb) ptype int32_t
type = long int
(gdb) whatis int32_t
type = long int

But for you ??? It seems to return an error!!
I really dislike to have to put hacks in again .... let see
what we can do.

See diff of the SourceManager.java.

If it works for you flip to "verify"
